statement.text: The aortic bifurcation at L4 divides into common iliac arteries, which further divide into external iliac (continuing to leg) and internal iliac/hypogastric (supplying pelvis), with the hypogastric providing critical collateral pathways and pelvic organ perfusion.

explanation.intuition: At the level of your belly button (roughly), the aorta splits into two common iliac arteries. Each then splits again: one branch continues down to become the main leg artery, while the other dives into the pelvis to feed the bladder, colon, buttocks, and reproductive organs.
explanation.key_insight: The internal iliac (hypogastric) artery is the key collateral pathway in aortoiliac occlusion. It must be preserved during EVAR when possible. Bilateral hypogastric occlusion risks buttock claudication, impotence, and ischemic colitis.
explanation.technical_details: Aortic bifurcation: L4 vertebral level, at umbilicus. Common iliac: 4-5cm length, divides at sacroiliac joint. External iliac: continues as femoral artery below inguinal ligament, gives inferior epigastric and deep circumflex iliac. Internal iliac branches: anterior division (bladder, rectum, uterus), posterior division (gluteal, lateral sacral). Collaterals: lumbar→iliolumbar, IMA→superior hemorrhoidal→middle hemorrhoidal.

anatomic_features.clinical_importance: Hypogastric preservation critical for pelvic organ and buttock perfusion

clinical_pearls: Aortic bifurcation is at L4 - approximately umbilicus level
Preserve at least one hypogastric during EVAR when possible
Bilateral hypogastric occlusion risks buttock claudication, impotence, colonic ischemia
